Explanation: The suggestion to inspect the right calf for swelling, discoloration, or deformities directly aligns with the criteria of assessing for visible abnormalities.

The suggestion of 'Palpation of the right calf to assess tenderness and temperature' is similar to the evaluation of tenderness and temperature differences, fulfilling the criteria of assessing for abnormalities.
The doctor did not suggest measuring calf circumference, which is a specific step to quantify swelling, and instead focused on visual inspection and comparison without quantification.
The doctor did not suggest a physical exam step that specifically assesses for movement exacerbating pain or limitations in the same manner as the assessment of range of motion in the ankle and knee.
The doctor did not suggest a Doppler examination or any similar step specifically aimed at evaluating venous or arterial flow issues.
The suggestion of the Dorsiflexion test (Homan's sign) directly assesses for signs of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) by checking for pain in the calf, which aligns with the criteria provided.
The doctor did not suggest any steps related to a neurological examination of the lower extremities, focusing instead on vascular and musculoskeletal assessments.

The doctor suggested checking for pulses in the dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial arteries, which is similar to assessing pulses in the lower extremities to evaluate arterial circulation and rule out vascular issues.
The suggested physical examination steps focus specifically on the calf and do not include an examination of the feet and ankles.
The doctor did not suggest any physical examination step related to assessing vital signs, which would be necessary to monitor changes in the patient's condition.
